title: Conservation of angular momentum - disks together

content.question: A disk with a rotational inertia of <math alttext="1.8 kilogram meters squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.8</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi><mo>·</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> is rotating counterclockwise about its center with an angular speed of <math alttext="6 radians per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>rad/s</mtext></math>. A second disk, which has a rotational inertia of <math alttext="1.2 kilogram meters squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi><mo>·</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, is rotating clockwise about its center with an angular speed of <math alttext="6 radians per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>rad/s</mtext></math> when it drops directly on top of, and sticks to, the first disk. The two disks then rotate together without slipping. What is the new angular speed of the disks?

choices.label: <math alttext="0 radians per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>rad/s</mtext></math>
<math alttext="1.2 radians per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>rad/s</mtext></math>
<math alttext="3.6 radians per scond" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.6</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>rad/s</mtext></math>
<math alttext="6.0 radians per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>6.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>rad/s</mtext></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="1.2 radians per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>rad/s</mtext></math>
